div0.head: Η

div1.head: ἤ
div1.sense: Conjunction with two chief senses, Disjunctive and Comparative.

DISJUNCTIVE, or, Lat. vel, to subjoin one or more clauses differing from the first, ἤκουσας ἢ οὐκ ἤκουσας ἢ κωφῇ λέγω; Aesch.: —ἤ . . , ἤ . . , either . . , or . . , Lat. aut . . , aut . . , Hom., etc.

in indirect Questions, εἰ . . , ἢ . . , whether . . , or . . , Lat. utrum . . , an . . , εἰδῶμεν εἰ νικῶμεν ἢ νικώμεθα Aesch.:—but in Hom. ἢ . . , ἢ (or ἦ) . . is used for εἰ, Lat. an, εἰπὲ ἢ . . , say whether . . , Od.

COMPARATIVE, than, as, Lat. quam, Hom., etc.: after Adjs. which imply comparison, as ἄλλος, ἕτερος, ἀλλοῖος, διπλάσιος, ἐναντίος, ἴδιος, πολλαπλάσιος, and after the Advs. πρίν, πρόσθεν; so, after Verbs implying comparison, βούλεσθαι ἤ . . to wish rather than . .; φθάνειν ἤ . . to come sooner than . . , etc.
ἤ sometimes joins two Comparatives, when they both refer to the same subject, ἐλαφρότεροι ἢ ἀφνειότεροι to be swifter rather than richer, Od.; ταχύτερα ἢ σοφώτερα Hdt.
rarely after a Sup., πλεῖστα θωυμάσια ἔχει Αἴγυπτος ἢ ἄλλη πᾶσα χώρη Hdt.
ἤ is often omitted with numerals after πλέων, ἐλάττων, μείων, as, ἔτη πλέω ἑβδομήκοντα Plat. [When ἢ οὐ, ἢ οὐκ come together in a verse, the two coalesce into one syll.]

div1.head: ἤ
div1.sense: an exclamation, to call oneʼs attention to a thing, ἤ, ἤ, σιώπα Ar.

div1.head: ἠβαιός
div1.sense: little, small, poor, slight, with negat. οὐδέ, οὔ οἱ ἔνι φρένες, οὐδʼ ἠβαιαί no sense is in him, no not the least, Hom.; οὔ οἱ ἔνι τρίχες, οὐδʼ ἠβαιαί no not even a few, Od.:—neut. as adv., οὐδʼ ἠβαιόν not in the least, not at all, Lat. ne tantillum quidem, Hom.; rarely without a negat., ἠβαιὸν ἀπὸ σπείους a little from the cave, Od.

div1.head: ἡβάσκω
div1.sense: to come to manʼs estate, come to oneʼs strength, Lat. pubescere, Xen.:—metaph. to be new, ἡβάσκει πενίη Anth.

div1.head: ἡβάω
div1.sense: to be at manʼs estate, to be in the prime of youth, ἀνὴρ οὐδὲ μάλʼ ἡβῶν not even in the prime and pride of life, Hom.; γυνὴ τέτορʼ ἡβώωσα (sc. ἔτη) i. e. being four years past puberty, Hes.; ἡβῶν when I was young, Ar.; οἱ ἡβῶντες the young, Ar.:—of plants, ἡμερὶς ἡβώωσα a young luxuriant vine, Od.
metaph. to be young, ἀεὶ γὰρ ἡβᾶι τοῖς γέρουσιν εὖ μαθεῖν learning is young even for the old, i. e. ʼtis never too late to learn, Aesch.; ἡβᾶι δῆμος the people is like a young man, Eur.

div1.head: ἡβηδόν
div1.sense: from the youth upwards, Hdt.

div1.head: ἥβη
div1.sense: manhood, youthful prime, youth, Lat. pubertas, νεηνίηι ἀνδρὶ ἐοικώς, τοῦπερ χαριεστάτη ἥβη Od.; ἥβης μέτρον ἱκέσθαι or ἱκάνειν ἡβάσκειν, Od.
youthful strength, vigour, πειρώμενος ἥβης Il.; ἥβηι πεποίθεα Od.
legally, ἥβη was the time before manhood, at Athens 16 years of age; at Sparta, 18, so that τὰ δέκα ἀφʼ ἥβης were men of 28, τὰ τετταράκοντα ἀφʼ ἥβης men of 58, and so on, Xen.: cf. ἔφηβος.
metaph. youthful cheer, merriment, δαιτὸς ἥβη Eur.: also youthful passion, fire, spirit, Pind.
a body of youth, the youth, Lat. juventus, Aesch.
as femin. prop. n., Ἥβη, Hebe, daughter of Zeus and Hera, wife of Hercules, Hom.

div1.head: ἡβητήριον
div1.sense: a place where young people meet, to eat and drink, exercise and amuse themselves, Plut.

div1.head: ἡβητής
div1.sense: youthful, at oneʼs prime, Hhymn., Eur.

div1.head: ἡβητικός
div1.sense: youthful, Lat. juvenilis, Xen.

div1.head: ἡβυλλιάω
div1.sense: to be youngish, Ar.

div1.head: ἠγάθεος
div1.sense: very divine, most holy, Hom.

div1.head: ἡγεμόνευμα
div1.sense: a leading: in Eur. ἁγεμόνευμα νεκροῖσι ἡγεμὼν νεκρῶν.

div1.head: ἡγεμονεύω
div1.sense: to be or act as ἡγεμών, to go before, lead the way, Hom.; ὁδὸν ἡγ. Od.; c. dat. pers. to lead the way for him, ῥόον ὕδατι ἡγεμόνευεν made a course for the water, Il.

to lead in war, to rule, command, c. dat., Il.; elsewhere, like most Verbs of ruling, c. gen., Il., Hdt., etc.:—absol. to have or take the command, Hdt., Plat.:—Pass. to be ruled, Thuc.; to be governor, τῆς Συρίας NTest.

div1.head: ἡγεμονία
div1.sense: a leading the way, going first, Hdt.
chief command, Hdt., Thuc., etc.; ἡγ. δικαστηρίων authority over them, Aeschin.

the hegemony or sovereignty of one state over a number of subordinates, as of Athens in Attica, Thebes in Boeotia:— the hegemony of Greece was wrested from Sparta by Athens; and the Peloponn. war was a struggle for this hegemony.
= Roman imperium, Plut.: the reign of the Emperor, NTest.
a division of the army, a command, Plut.

div1.head: ἡγεμονικός
div1.sense: ready to lead or guide, Xen.
fit to command, authoritative, leading, Xen., etc.
= Rom. Consularis, Plut.

div1.head: ἡγεμόσυνα
div1.sense: sc. ἱερά , τά, thank-offerings for safe conduct, Xen.

div1.head: ἡγεμών
div1.sense: one who leads, Lat. dux: and so,
in Od., a guide to shew the way, so Hdt., etc.; ἡγ. γενέσθαι τινὶ τῆς ὁδοῦ Hdt.
one who is an authority to others, Lat. dux, auctor, τοῖς νεωτέροις ἡγ. ἠθῶν γίγνεσθαι Plat.; ἡγεμόνα εἶναί τινος to be the cause of a thing, Xen., etc.

in Il., a leader, commander, chief, ἡγεμόνες Δαναῶν, φυλάκων, Il., etc.; ἔχοντες ἡγεμόνας τῶν πάνυ στρατηγῶν having some of the best generals as commanders, Thuc.: a chief, sovereign, Pind., Soph., etc.
= Rom. Emperor, Plut.: also a provincial governor, NTest.

div1.head: ἡγέομαι
div1.sense: Dep. to go before, lead the way, Hom., etc.:—c. dat. pers. to lead the way for him, guide, conduct, Hom.:—also, ὁδὸν ἡγήσασθαι to go before on the way, Lat. praeire viam, Od.
c. dat. pers. et gen. rei, to be oneʼs leader in a thing, ἀοιδὸς ἡμῖν ἡγείσθω ὀρχηθμοῖο Od.; ἡγ. τινι σοφίας, ὠιδῆς Pind., etc.:—and c. gen. rei only, ἡγ. νόμων to lead the song, Pind., etc.
c. acc. rei, to lead, conduct, τὰς πομπάς Dem., etc.
to lead an army or fleet, c. dat., Hom., etc.:—c. gen. to be the leader or commander of, Hom.
absol., οἱ ἡγούμενοι the rulers, Soph.; ἡγούμενοι ἐν τοῖς ἀδελφοῖς leading men, NTest.
to suppose, believe, hold, Lat. ducere, Hdt., etc.; ἡγ. τι εἶναι Hdt.
with an attributive word added, ἡγ. τινα βασιλέα to hold or regard as king, Hdt.; ἡγ. τι περὶ πολλοῦ Hdt.; περὶ πλείστου Thuc.
ἡγ. θεούς to believe in gods, Eur., etc.; cf. νομίζω II.
ἡγοῦμαι δεῖν, to think it fit, deem it necessary to do, c. inf., Dem.; without δεῖν, παθεῖν μᾶλλον ἡγησάμενοι ἤ . . Thuc.
the perf. is used in pass. sense, τὰ ἁγημένα τὰ νομιζόμενα, ap. Dem.

div1.head: ἠγερέθομαι
div1.sense: Epic form of ἀγείρομαι (Pass.) to gather together, assemble, Hom.
div1.etym: only in 3rd pl. pres. and imperf. ἠγερέθονται, ἠγερέθοντο, and inf. ἠγερέθεσθαι.

div1.head: ἡγέτης
div1.sense: a leader, Anth.

div1.head: ἡγηλάζω
div1.sense: to guide, lead, Od.; κακὸν μόρον ἡγ. to lead a wretched life, Od.

div1.head: ἡγητέον
div1.sense: one must lead, Xen.
one must suppose, Plat.

div1.head: ἡγητήρ
div1.sense: a guide, Soph.
a commander, Pind.

div1.head: ἡγήτωρ
div1.sense: a leader, commander, chief, Il.

div1.head: ἤγουν
div1.sense: that is to say, or rather, to define a word more correctly, Xen.

div1.head: ἠδέ
div1.sense: and, properly correlative to ἠ-μέν v. sub ἠμέν:— but, often without ἠμέν, just like καί, and, Il.:— ἠδὲ καί conjoined and also, Hom.

div1.head: ἡδέως
div1.etym: adverb of ἡδύς, v. ἡδύς III.

div1.head: ἤδη
div1.etym: related to νῦν, as Lat. jam to nunc
div1.sense: by this time, before this, already, or of the future, now, presently, forthwith, Hom.; νὺξ ἤδη τελέθει ʼtis already night, Il.; ἔτος τόδʼ ἤδη δέκατον Soph.:—so in a local relation, ἀπὸ ταύτης ἤδη Αἴγυπτος directly after this is Egypt, Hdt.
of the future, λέξον ὄφρα κεν ἤδη ταρπώμεθα Il.; στείχοις ἂν ἤδη Soph.
often joined with other words of time, ἤδη νῦν now already, Hom.; νῦν ἤδη Soph., etc.; ἤδη πάλαι Soph.; ἐπεὶ ἤδη, Lat. quum jam, Od., etc.

div1.head: ἥδομαι
div1.sense: to enjoy oneself, take delight, take oneʼs pleasure, Od., etc.—Construction:
with participle, ἥσατο πίνων Od.; ἥσθη ἀκούσας he was glad to have heard, Hdt., etc.
c. dat., ἥδεσθαί τινι to delight in or at a thing, Hdt., etc.; ἐπί τινι Xen., etc.;—rarely c. gen., πώματος ἥσθη he enjoyed the draught, Soph.
c. acc. and part., ἥσθην πατέρα τὸν ἀμὸν εὐλογοῦντά σε I was pleased to hear you praising him, Soph.
part. as an adj. glad, delighted, Ar.: also, like βουλομένωι, ἀσμένωι, in the phrase ἡδομένωι ἐστί μοί τι I am well pleased at the thing happening, Hdt., Plat.

div1.head: ἡδομένως
div1.sense: of ἥδομαι, with joy, gladly, Xen.

div1.head: ἡδονή
div1.sense: delight, enjoyment, pleasure, Lat. voluptas, Hdt., etc.; ἡδονῇ ἡσσᾶσθαι, χαρίζεσθαι to give way to pleasure, Thuc., Plat., etc.:—often with Prepositions in adv. sense, πρὸς or καθʼ ἡδονὴν λέγειν to speak so as to please another, Hdt., Attic; καθʼ ἡδονὴν κλύειν, ἀκούειν Soph., Dem.; καθʼ ἡδονήν or πρὸς ἡδ. ἐστί μοι Aesch.; ὃ μέν ἐστι πρὸς ἡδ. that which is agreeable, Dem.; ἐν ἡδονῇ ἐστί τινι it is a pleasure or delight to another, Hdt., etc.
a pleasure, a delight, Soph., Ar.
in pl. pleasures, pleasant lusts, Xen., NTest.

div1.head: ἦδος
div1.sense: delight, enjoyment, pleasure, δαιτὸς ἦδος pleasure from or in the feast, Hom.; ἀλλὰ τί μοι τῶν ἦδος; what delight have I there from? Il.

div1.head: ἡδυβόης
div1.sense: sweet-sounding, Eur., Anth.

div1.head: ἡδύγαμος
div1.sense: sweetening marriage, Anth.

div1.head: ἡδύγελως
div1.sense: sweetly laughing, Hhymn., Anth.

div1.head: ἡδύγλωσσος
div1.sense: sweet-tongued, Pind.

div1.head: ἡδυγνώμων
div1.sense: of pleasant mind, Xen.

div1.head: ἡδυεπής
div1.sense: sweet-speaking, Il., etc.: sweet-sounding, Pind.:—poet. fem. ἡδυέπεια, Hes.

div1.head: ἡδύθροος
div1.sense: sweet-strained, Eur.

div1.head: ἡδύλογος
div1.sense: sweet-speaking, sweet-voiced, Pind., Anth.
of persons, ἡδυλόγος, flattering, fawning, Eur.

div1.head: ἡδυλύρης
div1.sense: singing sweetly to the lyre, Anth.

div1.head: ἡδυμελής
div1.sense: sweet-strained, sweet-singing, Pind.

div1.head: ἡδυμελίφθογγος
div1.sense: of honey-sweet voice, Anth.

div1.head: ἡδυμιγής
div1.sense: sweetly-mixed, Anth.

div1.head: ἥδυμος
div1.sense: sweet, pleasant, Hhymn.

div1.head: ἡδύνω
div1.sense: to sweeten, season, give a flavour or relish to a thing, c. acc., Xen., etc.

div1.head: ἡδύοινος
div1.sense: producing sweet wine, Xen.:— ἡδύοινοι, οἱ, dealers in sweet wine, Xen.

div1.head: ἡδυπάθεια
div1.sense: pleasant living, luxury, Xen.

div1.head: ἡδυπαθέω
div1.sense: to live pleasantly, enjoy oneself, be luxurious, Xen.

div1.head: ἡδυπάθημα
div1.sense: enjoyment, Anth.

div1.head: ἡδύπνοος
div1.sense: sweet-breathing, Eur.; of musical sound, Pind.; of dreams, Soph.
sweet-smelling, fragrant, Anth.

div1.head: ἡδύπολις
div1.sense: dear to the people, Soph.

div1.head: ἡδυπότης
div1.sense: fond of drinking, Anth.

div1.head: ἡδύποτος
div1.sense: sweet to drink, Od.

div1.head: ἥδυσμα
div1.sense: that which gives a relish or flavour, seasoning, sauce, Ar., Xen., etc.

div1.head: ἡδύς
div1.sense: sweet to the taste or smell, Hom.; to the hearing, Hom.; then of any pleasant feeling or state, as sleep, Hom.:—c. inf., ἡδὺς δρακεῖν Aesch.; ἡδὺς ἀκοῦσαι λόγος Plat.:— ἡδύ ἐστι or γίγνεται it is pleasant, Hom., etc.:—so, οὔ μοι ἥδιόν ἐστι λέγειν I had rather not say, Hdt.:—neut. as Subst., τὰ ἡδέα pleasures, Thuc.:—neut. as adv., sweetly, Il., etc.
after Hom., of persons, pleasant, welcome, Soph.
well-pleased, glad, Soph., Dem.; in addressing a person, ὦ ἥδιστε, Horaceʼs dulcissime rerum, Plat.
like εὐήθης, innocent, simple, ὡς ἡδὺς εἶ Plat.

adv. ἡδέως, sweetly, pleasantly, with pleasure, Soph., Eur., etc.; ἡδέως ἂν ἐροίμην I would gladly ask, should like to ask, Dem.;— ἡδ. ἔχειν τι to be pleased or content with, Eur.; ἡδ. ἔχειν πρός τινα or τινί to be kind, well-disposed to one, Dem.:— comp. ἥδιον Plat., etc.:—Sup., ἥδιστα Plat.

div1.head: ἡδυφαής
div1.sense: sweet-shining, Anth.

div1.head: ἡδύφρων
div1.sense: sweet-minded, Anth.

div1.head: ἡδυφωνία
div1.sense: sweetness of voice or sound, Babr.

div1.head: ἡδύφωνος
div1.sense: sweet-voiced, Sapph..

div1.head: ἡδυχαρής
div1.sense: sweetly joyous, Anth.

div1.head: ἡδύχροος
div1.sense: of sweet complexion, Anth.

div1.head: ἠερέθομαι
div1.etym: Epic for ἀείρομαι, Pass., only found in3 pl. pres. and imperf. ἠερέθονται, -οντο
div1.sense: to hang floating or waving in the air, Il.:—metaph., ὁπλοτέρων ἀνδρῶν φρένες ἠερέθονται young menʼs minds turn with every wind, Il.

div1.head: ἠέριος
div1.sense: early, with early morn, Il.
in the air, high in air, Anth.

div1.head: ἠεροδίνης
div1.sense: wheeling in mid air, Anth.

div1.head: ἠεροειδής
div1.sense: of dark and cloudy look, cloud-streaked, of the sea, Od.: generally, dark, murky, Od.:—neut. as adv., in the far distance, dimly, ὅσσον τʼ ἠεροειδὲς ἀνὴρ ἴδεν Il.

div1.head: ἠερόεις
div1.sense: hazy, murky, Il.; ἠερόεντα κέλευθα the murky road (i. e. death), Od.

div1.head: ἠερόθεν
div1.sense: from air, Anth.

div1.head: ἠεροφοῖτις
div1.sense: walking in darkness, Il.

div1.head: ἠερόφωνος
div1.sense: sounding through air, loud-voiced, Il.

div1.head: ἠθάς
div1.sense: accustomed to a thing, acquainted with it, c. gen., Soph.
absol. accustomed, usual, Eur.: of animals, tame, domestic, Lat. mansuetus, Ar.:—as neut., = ἦθος, τὰ καινά γʼ ἐκ τῶν ἠθάδων ἡδίονʼ ἐστί Eur.

div1.head: ἠθεῖος
div1.sense: trusty, honoured, ἠθεῖε sir, Il.; ἠθείη κεφαλή Il.; ἀλλά μιν ἠθεῖον καλέω I will call him my honoured lord, Od.

div1.head: ἠθέω
div1.sense: to sift, strain:—Pass. to be strained, Plat.

div1.head: ἠθικός
div1.sense: of or for morals, ethical, moral, Arist.; τὰ ἠθικά a treatise on morals, Arist.
shewing moral character, expressive thereof, Arist.:— adv., ἠθικῶς λέγειν Arist.

div1.head: ἡθμός
div1.sense: a strainer, Eur.; of the eyelashes, Xen.

div1.head: ἠθοποιέω
div1.sense: to form manners or character, Plut.

div1.head: ἠθοποιός
div1.sense: forming character, Plut.

div1.head: ἦθος
div1.sense: an accustomed place: in pl. the haunts or abodes of animals, Hom., Hdt.
custom, usage, Hes., Hdt.
of man, his disposition, character, Lat. ingenium, mores, Hes., Attic; ὦ μιαρὸν ἦθος, addressed to a person, Soph.
in pl., generally, of manners, like Lat. mores, Hes., Hdt., Thuc. rare collat. form of ἠθέω.

div1.head: ἤϊα
div1.sense: provisions for a journey, Epic word for ἐφόδια, Lat. viaticum, Hom.:—generally, λύκων ἤια food for wolves, Il.
husks or chaff, Od.

div1.head: ἠίθεος
div1.sense: a youth just come to manhood, but not yet married, παρθένος ἠίθεός τε Hom.; χοροὺς παρθένων τε καὶ ἠιθέων Hdt.
rare as fem., ἠιθέη παρθένος.

div1.head: ἠϊόεις
div1.sense: with banks, high-banked, Il.

div1.head: ἤϊος
div1.sense: epith. of Phoebus, ἤϊε Φοῖβε Il. Prob. from the cry ἤ, ἤ, cf. ἰήϊος, εὔϊος.

div1.head: ἠϊών
div1.sense: a sea-bank, shore, beach, Hdt., etc.; a river-bank, Aesch.

div1.head: ἦκα
div1.sense: of place or motion, slightly, a little, softly, gently, Hom.
of Sound, stilly, softly, low, Il.
of Sight, softly, smoothly, ἦκα στίλβοντες ἐλαίῳ with oil soft shining, Il.
of Time, by little and little, Anth.

div1.head: ἤκεστος
div1.sense: untouched by the goad, of young heifers reserved for sacrifices, Il.

div1.head: ἤκιστος
div1.sense: ἤκιστος ἐλαυνέμεν, the gentlest or slowest in driving, Il.

div1.head: ἥκιστος
div1.etym: Sup. of the comp. ἥσσων, the Posit. in use being μικρός,
div1.sense: least:—as adv. ἥκιστα, least, Soph., etc.; οὐχ ἥκιστα, ἀλλὰ μάλιστα Hdt.; ὡς ἥκιστα as little as possible, Thuc.
often in reply to a question, nay not so, not at all, Lat. minime, Soph., etc.; ἥκιστά γε minime vero, Soph.

div1.head: ἥκω
div1.sense: to have come, be present, be here, Lat. adesse, properly in a perf. sense, with the imperf. ἧκον as plup., I had come, and fut. ἥξω as fut. perf. I shall have come, directly opp. to οἴχομαι to be gone, while ἔρχομαι to come or go serves as pres. to both, Hom., etc.:—to return, Xen.
to have reached a point, ἐς τοσήνδʼ ὕβριν Soph.; ἐς τοσοῦτον ἀμαθίας Plat.
διʼ ὀργῆς ἥκειν to be angry, Soph.; cf. διά A. IV.

like ἔχω B. II, εὖ ἥκειν τινός to be well off for a thing, have plenty of it, as, εὖ ἡκ.τοῦ βίου Hdt.; καλῶς αὐτοῖς ἧκον βίου as they had come to a good age, Eur.; ὧδε γένους ἡκ. τινί to be this degree of kin to him, Eur.:—also, εὖ ἥκειν, absol., to be well off, flourishing, Hdt.:—c. gen. only, σὺ δὲ δυνάμιος ἥκεις μεγάλης thou art in great power, Hdt.
of things, to be brought, Eur., etc.; ἵνʼ ἥκει τὰ μαντεύματα what they have come to, Soph.
to concern, relate, or belong to, εἴς ἐμʼ ἥκει τὰ πράγματα Ar.
to depend upon, ἐπί τι Dem.

div1.head: ἠλαίνω
div1.sense: to wander, stray, Theocr.

div1.head: ἠλάκατα
div1.sense: the wool on the distaff, Od.

div1.head: ἠλακάτη
div1.sense: a distaff, Lat. colus, on which the wool is put, Hom., etc.; ἡ ἠλ. τοῦ ἀτράκτου the stalk of the spindle, Plat.

div1.head: ἠλασκάζω
div1.sense: lengthd. form of ἠλάσκω, Il.
c. acc. to flee from, shun, Od.

div1.head: ἠλάσκω
div1.sense: to wander, stray, roam about, Il.

div1.head: ἠλέκτρινος
div1.sense: made of ἤλεκτρον, Luc.

div1.head: ἤλεκτρον
div1.sense: electron, a word sometimes used to denote amber, as prob. in Hom., Hes. and Hdt.;—sometimes pale gold, a compound of 1 part of silver to 4 of gold, Soph., etc.—In Ar. ἐκπιπτουσῶν τῶν ἠλέκτρων, the ἤλεκτροι are prob. the pegs of the lyre made of or inlaid with electron.

div1.head: ἠλεκτροφαής
div1.sense: amber-gleaming, Eur.

div1.head: ἠλέκτωρ
div1.sense: the beaming sun, Il.; as adj., ἠλέκτωρ Ὑπερίων beaming Hyperion, Il.

div1.head: ἠλέματος
div1.sense: idle, vain, trifling, Theocr., Anth.

div1.head: ἠλεός
div1.sense: astray, distraught, crazed, Od.; also in apocop. form ἠλέ, Il.: ἠλεά as adv. foolishly, Anth.
act. distracting, crazing, οἶνος Od.

div1.head: ἡλιάζομαι
div1.sense: Dep.:— to sit in the court Ἡλιαία, be a Heliast, Ar.

div1.head: ἡλιαία
div1.sense: at Athens, a public place or hall, in which the chief law-court was held, Ar.
the supreme court, ap. Dem.

div1.head: ἡλιάς
div1.sense: fem. adj. of the sun, ap. Luc.

div1.head: ἡλιαστής
div1.sense: a juryman of the court ἡλιαία, a Heliast, Ar.

div1.head: ἡλιαστικός
div1.sense: of, for, or like a Heliast, Ar.

div1.head: ἠλίβατος
div1.sense: high, steep, precipitous, epith. of rocky crags, Hom., Hes., etc.; of the throne of Zeus, Ar.
in Od. 9. 243 ἠλίβατος πέτρη, it seems to mean enormous, huge.
= Lat. altus, deep, profound, Hes., Eur.

div1.head: ἤλιθα
div1.sense: enough, sufficiently, Lat. satis, ληὶς ἤλιθα πολλή Il.; δύη ἤλιθα πολλή Od., etc.

div1.head: ἠλιθιάζω
div1.sense: to speak or act idly, foolishly, Ar.

div1.head: ἠλίθιος
div1.sense: idle, vain, random, Pind., Aesch.
of persons, stupid, foolish, silly, like μάταιος, Hdt., Ar., etc. adv. -ίως, Plat.; neut. ἠλίθιον as adv., Ar.

div1.head: ἠλιθιότης
div1.sense: folly, silliness, Plat.

div1.head: ἠλιθιόω
div1.sense: to make foolish, distract, craze, Aesch.

div1.head: ἡλικία
div1.sense: time of life, age, Lat. aetas, Il.;—acc. used absol. in age, νέος ἡλικίην Hdt.; so in dat., ἡλικίᾳ ὢν νέος Thuc.; πόρρω τῆς ἡλ. advanced in years, Plat.

mostly, the flower or prime of life from about 17 to 45, manʼs estate, manhood, ἐν ἁλικίᾳ πρώτᾳ Pind.; ἐν ἡλικίᾳ εἶναι to be of age, Plat., etc.; so, ἡλικίαν ἔχειν, εἰς ἡλ. ἐλθεῖν Plat.; ἡλικίαν ἔχειν, c. inf., to be of fit age for doing, Hdt.; οἱ ἐν ἡλικίᾳ men of serviceable age, Thuc.
youthful heat and passion, ἡλικίῃ ἐπιτρέπειν Hdt.
as collective Noun, = οἱ ἥλικες, those of the same age, fellows, comrades, Il., Thuc.
time, ταῦτα ἡλικίην ἂν εἴη κατὰ Λάϊον about the time of Laius, Hdt.
an age, generation, Lat. saeculum, Dem., etc.
of the body, stature, growth, as a sign of age, Hdt., Plat.

div1.head: ἡλικιώτης
div1.sense: an equal in age, fellow, comrade, Lat. aequalis, Hdt., Ar., etc.

div1.head: ἡλικιῶτις
div1.sense: Fem. of ἡλικιώτης, Luc.; ἡλ. ἱστορία contemporary history, Plut.

div1.head: ἡλίκος
div1.sense: as big as, Lat. quantus, Ar., Dem.
of age, as old as, Ar., etc.
in expressions of wonder, θαυμάσια ἡλίκα extraordinarily great, as in Lat. mirum quantum, Dem.

div1.head: ἧλιξ
div1.sense: of the same age, Od., Pind.: c. gen. of the same age with, Aesch.
as Subst. a fellow, comrade, Hdt., Aesch., etc.

div1.head: ἡλιόβλητος
div1.sense: sun-stricken, sun-burnt, Eur.

div1.head: ἡλιοειδής
div1.sense: like the sun, beaming, Plat.

div1.head: ἡλιόκαυστος
div1.sense: sun-burnt, Theocr.

div1.head: ἡλιομανής
div1.sense: sun-mad, mad for love of the sun, Ar.

div1.head: ἡλιόομαι
div1.sense: Pass. to live in the sun, Plat.; τὸ ἡλιούμενον a sunny spot, Xen.

div1.head: ἥλιος
div1.sense: the sun, Lat. sol, Hom., etc.; ὁρᾶν φάος ἠελίοιο, i.e. to be alive, Il.—The Sun furnished the earliest mode of determining the points of the heaven, πρὸς ἠῶ τʼ ἠέλιόν τε, i. e. towards the East, opp. to πρὸς ζόφον, Hom.; πρὸς ἠῶ τε καὶ ἡλίου ἀνατολάς, opp. to πρὸς ἑσπέρην, Hdt.
day, a day, like Lat. soles, Pind., Eur.: so in pl. hot sunny days, Thuc.
as prop. n., Helios, the sun-god, Hom.; in later Poets = Apollo, Aesch., etc.

div1.head: ἡλιοστερής
div1.sense: depriving of sun, i. e. shading from the sun, Soph.

div1.head: ἡλιοστιβής
div1.sense: sun-trodden, Aesch.

div1.head: ἠλιτοεργός
div1.sense: missing the work, failing in oneʼs aim, Anth.

div1.head: ἠλιτόμηνος
div1.sense: missing the right month, i. e. untimely born, Il.

div1.head: ἡλιώτης
div1.sense: of the sun, Epic ἠελιῶτις Anth.:— οἱ ἡλιῶται the inhabitants of the sun, Luc.

div1.head: ἧλος
div1.sense: a nail: in Hom. only for ornament, a nail-head or stud.
after Hom. a nail to fasten with, Pind., Xen., etc.

div1.head: ἠλύγη
div1.sense: a shadow, shade: metaph., δίκης ἠλύγη the obscurity of a lawsuit, Ar.

div1.head: Ἠλύσιον
div1.sense: the Elysian fields, Lat. Elysium, Od.; in pl., Anth. Hom. places it on the west border of the earth, near to Ocean; Hesiodʼs Elysium is in the μακάρων νῆσοι.

div1.head: Ἠλύσιος
div1.sense: Elysian, Anth.

div1.head: ἤλυσις
div1.sense: a step, Eur.

div1.head: ἠμαθόεις
div1.sense: sandy, Hom.

div1.head: ἧμαι
div1.sense: to be seated, sit, Hom., etc.:— to sit still, sit idle, Il., etc.: of an army, to lie encamped, Il.:—of a spy, to lurk, Il.:— later, of places, to lie, be situated, Hdt.; ἡμένωι ἐν χώρωι εἱαμενῇ, in a low, sunken place, Theocr.:—rarely c. acc., σέλμα ἧσθαι to be seated on a bench, Aesch.; ἧσθαι Σιμόεντος κοίτας Eur.

div1.head: ἧμα
div1.sense: that which is thrown, a dart, javelin, Il.

div1.head: ἦμαρ
div1.sense: day, Hom.; νύκτας τε καὶ ἦμαρ by night and day, Il.; ἦμαρ by day, Hes.; μέσον ἦμ. mid- day, Il.; δείελον ἦμ. evening, Od.

in Hom. with Adjs. to describe a state or condition, αἴσιμον, ὀλέθριον, μόρσιμον, νηλεὲς ἦμαρ the day of destiny, of death; ἐλεύθερον, δούλιον, ἀναγκαῖον ἦμαρ the day of freedom, of slavery; νόστιμον ἦμαρ, etc.
of the seasons, ἤματʼ ὀπωρινῇ, ἤματι χειμερίῳ Il.

with Preps. ἐπʼ ἤματι day by day, daily, Od.; also, in a day, for a day, Hom.: —so, ἐπʼ ἦμαρ by day, Soph.; for a day, Eur.:— κατʼ ἦμαρ day by day, Lat. quotidie, Soph.; κατʼ ἦμαρ ἀεί Soph.; but κατʼ ἦμαρ, also, this day, to-day, Lat. hodie, Soph.:— παρʼ ἦμαρ every other day, Pind., Soph.

div1.head: ἡμαρτημένως
div1.etym: adverb part. perf. pass. of ἁμαρτάνω,
div1.sense: faultily, Plat.

div1.head: ἠμάτιος
div1.sense: by day, Od.
day by day, daily, Il.

div1.head: ἡμεδαπός
div1.sense: of our land or country, native, Lat. nostras, Ar.

div1.head: ἠμελημένως
div1.etym: adverb part. perf. pass. of ἀμελέω,

div1.head: ἠμέν
div1.sense: Epic Conjunction, correlative to ἠ-δέ, as well .. , as also . . , Lat. et . . , et . . , but sometimes disjunctive, like Lat. vel . . , vel . . , Hom.

div1.head: ἡμέρα
div1.sense: day, Hom., etc.:—phrases for day-break, ἅμα ἡμέρᾳ or ἅμα τῇ ἡμέρᾳ Xen.; ἡμ. διαλάμπει or ἐκλάμπει Ar.; ἡμ. ὑποφαίνεται Xen.; γίγνεται or ἐστὶ πρὸς ἡμέραν Xen.
with Adjs. to describe a state or time of life, ἐπίπονος ἡμ. a life of misery, Soph.; λυπρὰν ἄγειν ἡμ. Eur.; αἱ μακραὶ ἡμέραι length of days, Soph.; νέα ἡμ. youth, Eur.
poet. for time, ἡμ. κλίνει τε κἀνάγει πάλιν ἅπαντα τἀνθρώπεια Soph.
absol. usages,
in gen., τριῶν ἡμερέων within three days, Hdt.; ἡμερῶν ὀλίγων within a few days, Thuc.: —also, ἡμέρας by day, Plat.; δὶς τῆς ἡμέρης ἑκάστης twice every day, Hdt.
in dat., τῇδε τῇ ἡμέρᾳ on this day, Soph.; so, τῇδʼ ἐν ἡμέρᾳ Soph.
in acc., πᾶσαν ἡμ. all day, Hdt.; τρίτην ἡμ. ἥκων three days after oneʼs arrival, Thuc.; τὰς ἡμέρας in daytime Xen.

with Preps., ἀνὰ πᾶσαν ἡμ. every day, Hdt.:— διʼ ἡμέρης, Attic -ρας, the whole day long, Hdt.; διὰ τρίτης ἡμ. every third day, Lat. tertio quoque die, Hdt.; διʼ ἡμ. πολλῶν at a distance of many days, Thuc.: — ἐξ ἡμέρας by day, Soph.:— ἐφʼ ἡμέραν sufficient for the day, Hdt., etc.; but, τοὐφʼ ἡμέραν day by day, Eur.:— καθʼ ἡμέραν by day, Aesch.; but commonly day by day, daily, Soph., etc.; τὸ καθʼ ἡμ., absol., every day, Ar., etc.;— μεθʼ ἡμέραν at mid- day, Hdt., etc.

div1.head: ἡμερεύω
div1.sense: to spend the day, Xen., etc.: —absol. to travel the whole day, Aesch.
to pass oneʼs days, live, Soph.

div1.head: ἡμερήσιος
div1.sense: for the day, by day, ἡμ. φάος light as of the day, Aesch.
a day long, ἡμ. ὁδός a dayʼs journey, Hdt., Plat., etc.

div1.head: ἡμερία
div1.sense: sc. ὥρα, ἡμέρα, Soph.

div1.head: ἡμερινός
div1.sense: of day, Plat.; ἄγγελος ἡμ. a day-messenger, Xen.

div1.head: ἡμέριος
div1.sense: for a day, lasting but a day, Soph., Eur.

div1.head: ἡμερίς
div1.sense: as Subst., ἡμερίς (sc. ἄμπελος) , the cultivated vine, opp. to ἀγριάς, Od.: but distinguished from ἀμπελίς by Ar.

div1.head: ἡμεροδρομέω
div1.sense: to be an ἡμεροδρόμος, Luc.

div1.head: ἡμεροδρόμος
div1.sense: as Subst. a courier, Hdt.

div1.head: ἡμερόκοιτος
div1.sense: sleeping by day, Hes., Eur.

div1.head: ἡμερολεγδόν
div1.sense: by count of days, Aesch.

div1.head: ἡμερολογέω
div1.sense: to count by days, Hdt.

div1.head: ἡμερολόγιον
div1.sense: a calendar, Plut.

div1.head: ἡμεροσκόπος
div1.sense: watching by day, Aesch., Ar.:—as Subst., a day-watcher, Hdt., Soph., etc.

div1.head: ἥμερος
div1.sense: tame, tamed, reclaimed, Lat. mansuetus, of animals, Od., Plat.; so, τὰ ἥμερα alone, Xen.
of plants and trees, cultivated, Lat. sativus, Hdt., etc.
of men, civilised, gentle, Hdt., Dem.; so of a lion, Aesch.

div1.head: ἡμερότης
div1.sense: tameness:—of men, gentleness, kindness, Plat.

div1.head: ἡμερόφαντος
div1.sense: appearing by day, Aesch.

div1.head: ἡμερόω
div1.sense: to tame, make tame, of wild beasts, Plat.
of countries, to clear them of robbers and wild beasts, as Hercules and Theseus did, Pind., Aesch.:—also, to tame by conquest, subdue, Hdt.
of men also, to soften, civilise, Plat.

div1.head: ἡμέρωσις
div1.sense: a taming: civilising, Plut.

div1.head: ἡμέτερος
div1.sense: our, Lat. noster, Hom., etc.; εἰς ἡμέτερον (sc. δῶμα) Od.; so, ἡμέτερόνδε Od.; ἡ ἡμετέρα (sc. χώρα) Thuc.; τὰ ἡμέτερα φρονεῖν to take our part, Xen.
sometimes for ἐμός, Od.

div1.head: ἡμιάνθρωπος
div1.sense: a half-man, Luc.

div1.head: ἡμιβραχής
div1.sense: sodden, Anth.

div1.head: ἡμίβρωτος
div1.sense: half-eaten, Xen.

div1.head: ἡμιγένειος
div1.sense: but half-bearded, Theocr.

div1.head: ἡμίγυμνος
div1.sense: half-naked, Luc.: so ἡμι-γύναιος, ον, Suid.; ἡμίγυνος, ον, Synes.

div1.head: ἡμιδαής
div1.sense: half-divided, half-mangled, Anth.

div1.head: ἡμιδαρεικόν
div1.sense: a half-daric, Xen.

div1.head: ἡμιδεής
div1.sense: wanting half, half-full, Xen., Anth.

div1.head: ἡμίδουλος
div1.sense: a half-slave, Eur.

div1.head: ἡμίεκτον
div1.sense: a half-ἑκτεύς, i. e. 1/12 of a medimnus, Dem.

div1.head: ἡμιέλλην
div1.sense: a half-Greek, Luc.

div1.head: ἡμιεργής
div1.sense: half-made, half-finished, Luc.

div1.head: ἡμίεφθος
div1.sense: half-boiled, half-cooked, Luc.

div1.head: ἡμιθαλής
div1.sense: half-green, Anth.

div1.head: ἡμιθανής
div1.sense: half-dead, Anth.

div1.head: ἡμίθεος
div1.sense: a half-god, demigod, Il., Hes.

div1.head: ἡμίθραυστος
div1.sense: half-broken, Eur., Anth.

div1.head: ἡμικλήριον
div1.sense: half the inheritance, Dem.

div1.head: ἡμίκυκλον
div1.sense: a semicircle, the front seats in the theatre, Plut.

div1.head: ἡμίλευκος
div1.sense: half-white, Luc.

div1.head: ἡμιμανής
div1.sense: half-mad, Aeschin., Luc.

div1.head: ἡμιμάραντος
div1.sense: half-withered, Luc.

div1.head: ἡμιμέδιμνον
div1.sense: a half-μέδιμνος, Dem.

div1.head: ἡμιμεθής
div1.sense: half-drunk, Anth.

div1.head: ἡμιμναῖον
div1.sense: a half-mina, Xen., etc.

div1.head: ἡμιμόχθηρος
div1.sense: half-evil, half a villain, Plat.

div1.head: ἡμίξηρος
div1.sense: half-dry, Anth.

div1.head: ἡμιόλιος
div1.sense: containing one and a half, half as much again, Lat. sesquialter, Plat.:—c. gen. half as large again as, half as much again as, Hdt., Xen.
ἡμιολία ναῦς a ship with one and a half banks of oars, Theophr.

div1.head: ἡμιόνειος
div1.sense: of, belonging to a mule, ἅμαξα ἡμ. a car drawn by mules, Hom.

div1.head: ἡμίονος
div1.sense: a half-ass, i. e. a mule, Hom., etc.:— proverb., ἐπεὰν ἡμίονοι τέκωσι, i. e. never, Hdt.
the ἡμ. ἀγροτέρα of Il. 2. 851 is prob. the wild ass.
as adj., βρέφος ἡμίονον a mule-foal, Il.; ἡμ. βασιλεύς a mule-king, half-Mede half-Persian, Orac. ap. Hdt.

div1.head: ἡμίοπτος
div1.sense: half-roasted, Luc.

div1.head: ἠμί
div1.sense: I say, Lat. inquam, used to repeat something with emphasis, παῖ ἠμί, παῖ boy I say, boy! Ar.:—imperf. ἦν, 3rd sg. ἦ, καὶ σχέθε χεῖρα he spake and held his hand, Il.; in Attic, ἦν δʼ ἐγώ said I, Plat.; ἦ δʼ ὅς said he, Ar., Plat.

div1.head: ἡμι-
div1.sense: Insep. Prefix, half-, Lat. semi-.

div1.head: ἡμιπέλεκκον
div1.sense: a half-axe, i. e. a one-edged axe, Il.

div1.head: ἡμίπεπτος
div1.sense: half-cooked, Plut.

div1.head: ἡμίπλεθρον
div1.sense: a half-πλέθρον, Hdt., Xen.

div1.head: ἡμιπλίνθιον
div1.sense: a half-plinth, a brick (two of which formed a plinth), Hdt.

div1.head: ἡμίπνοος
div1.sense: half-breathing, half-alive, Batr.

div1.head: ἡμιπόνηρος
div1.sense: half-evil, Arist.

div1.head: ἡμιπύρωτος
div1.sense: half-burnt, Anth.

div1.head: ἡμίσπαστος
div1.sense: half-pulled down, Anth.

div1.head: ἡμισταδιαῖος
div1.sense: of half a stadium, Luc.

div1.head: ἡμιστρατιώτης
div1.sense: a half-soldier, Luc.

div1.head: ἡμιστρόγγυλος
div1.sense: half-round, Luc.

div1.head: ἥμισυς
div1.sense: half, Lat. semis, used both as adj. and Subst.:

as adj., ἡμίσεες λαοί half the people, Hom.; ἥμισυς λόγος half the tale, Aesch., etc.;—c. gen., like a comp., ἥμισυ οὗ διενοεῖτο half of what he intended, Thuc.:— also with its Subst. in gen., τῶν νήσων τὰς ἡμίσεας half of the islands, Hdt.; αἱ ἡμίσειαι τῶν νεῶν Thuc.; ὁ ἥμισυς τοῦ ἀριθμοῦ Plat.
as Subst.,
neut., ἥμισυ τιμῆς, ἐνάρων, ἀρετῆς Hom.; πλέον ἥμισυ παντός, Hes.; mostly with Art., τὸ ἡμ. τοῦ στρατοῦ Thuc., etc.;—also in pl., ἄρτων ἡμίσεα Xen.
fem., ἡ ἡμ. τοῦ τιμήματος Plat.; ἐφʼ ἡμισείᾳ up to one half, Dem.

div1.head: ἡμιτάλαντον
div1.sense: a half-talent, as a weight, Il.; τρία ἡμιτάλαντα three half-talents, Hdt., but τρίτον ἡμιτάλαντον two talents and a half, Hdt.

div1.head: ἡμιτέλεια
div1.sense: a remission of half the tribute, Luc.

div1.head: ἡμιτέλεστος
div1.sense: half-finished, Thuc.

div1.head: ἡμιτελής
div1.sense: half-finished, δόμος ἡμ. a house but half complete, i. e. wanting its lord and master, Il.; ἡμ. ἀνήρ, opp. to τελείως, ἀγαθός, Xen.

div1.head: ἡμίτομος
div1.sense: half cut through, cut in two, Mosch.
as Subst., ἡμίτομον, ου, τό, a half, Hdt.

div1.head: ἡμιτύβιον
div1.sense: a stout linen cloth, towel, napkin, Ar. (An Egypt. word.)

div1.head: ἡμιφαής
div1.sense: half-shining, Anth.

div1.head: ἡμιφάλακρος
div1.sense: half-bald, Anth.

div1.head: ἡμίφαυλος
div1.sense: half-knavish, Luc.

div1.head: ἡμίφλεκτος
div1.sense: half-burnt, Theocr., Luc.

div1.head: ἡμιωβελιαῖος
div1.sense: worth half an obol, Ar.: as large as a half-obol, Xen.

div1.head: ἡμιωβέλιον
div1.sense: a half-obol, Xen.

div1.head: ἦμος
div1.sense: at which time, when, Hom.
while, so long as, Soph.

div1.head: ἠμύω
div1.sense: to bow down, sink, drop, ἑτέρωσʼ ἤμυσε κάρη his head dropped to one side, Il.; ἤμυσε καρήατι bowed with his head, of a horse, Il.; of a cornfield, ἐπὶ δʼ ἠμύει ἀσταχύεσσι it bows or waves with its ears, Il.: metaph. of cities, to nod to their fall, totter, Il.

div1.head: ἥμων
div1.sense: a thrower, darter, slinger, Il.

div1.head: ἠνεμόεις
div1.sense: windy, airy, Hom., etc.
of motion, rapid, rushing, Aesch.

div1.head: ἡνία
div1.sense: reins, Hom., Hes., Pind.

div0.div1: ἡνία ἡ,the bridle (in riding), the reins (in driving), like the Homeric ἡνία, τά) mostly in pl., Pind., etc.; πρὸς ἡνίας μάχεσθαι Aesch.; in sg., ἐπισχὼν ἡνίαν Soph. metaph., χαλάσαι τὰς ἡνίας τοῖς λόγοις to give oneʼs words free reins, Plat.; τῆς Πυκνὸς τὰς ἡνίας παραδοῦναί τινι Plat. as a military term, ἐφʼ ἡνίαν to the left, Plut.

div1.head: ἡνίκα
div1.etym: adverb of Time, relat. to τηνίκα
div1.sense: at which time, when, Od., Trag.: also causal, since, Pind., Attic
with Opt. in orat. obl., or to denote an uncertain or repeated occurrence in past time, whenever, Soph., etc.
ἡνίκʼ ἄν, like ὅταν, with Subj., of the future, whenever, Soph., etc.

div1.head: ἡνιοποιεῖον
div1.sense: a saddlerʼs shop, Xen.

div1.head: ἡνιοστροφέω
div1.sense: to guide by reins, Aesch., Eur.

div1.head: ἡνιοστρόφος
div1.sense: one who guides by reins, a charioteer, Soph.

div1.head: ἡνιοχεία
div1.sense: chariot-driving, Plat.

div1.head: ἡνιοχεύω
div1.sense: to act as charioteer, Hom.:—metaph. to guide, Anth.

div1.head: ἡνιοχέω
div1.sense: to hold the reins, Xen.
c. acc. to drive, guide, Hdt.: metaph. to direct, Ar.:—Pass. to be guided, Xen.

div1.head: ἡνιοχικός
div1.sense: of or for driving, Plat.: ἡ -κή (sc. τέχνη) the art of driving, Plat.

div1.head: ἡνίοχος
div1.sense: one who holds the reins, a driver, charioteer, opp. to παραιβάτης (the warrior by his side), Il.
generally a chariot-driver, as in the games, Pind., Attic:—in Theogn., a rider.
metaph. a guide, governor, Pind., Ar.

div1.head: ἦνις
div1.sense: a year old, yearling, Hom.

div1.head: ἠνορέα
div1.sense: manhood, Hom.: manly beauty, Il.:—in pl. praises of manhood, Pind.

div1.head: ἦνοψ
div1.etym: in Hom., always in phrase ἤνοπι χαλκῷ,
div1.sense: with gleaming, glittering brass.

div1.head: ἤν
div1.sense: Interject. see! see there! lo! Lat. en! Ar.:—also ἠνίδε, i. e. ἢν ἴδε, Theocr.

div1.head: ἤνπερ
div1.etym: related to εἴπερ, as ἤν (ἐάν) to εἰ, Xen.

div1.head: ἤνυστρον
div1.sense: the fourth stomach of ruminating animals, a favourite dish at Athens, tripe, Ar.

div1.head: ἠοῖος
div1.sense: morning, Ar.:— ἡ ἠοίη (sc. ὥρα) , the morning, Od.
toward morning, eastern, Od., Hdt.
αἱ Ἠοῖαι was a poem of Hesiod, in which each sentence began with ἢ οἵη.

div1.head: ᾐόνιος
div1.sense: on the shore, Anth.

div1.head: ἠπανία
div1.sense: want, Anth.

div1.head: ἧπαρ
div1.sense: the liver, Hom., etc.:— ὑφʼ ἥπατος φέρειν, of pregnant women, Eur.:—in Trag. as the seat of the passions, anger, fear, etc., answering therefore to our "heart."

div1.head: ᾗ
div1.sense: dat. sg. fem. of relat. Pron. ὅς, ἥ, ὁ, Hom.: freq. in adverb. sense
of Place, which way, where, whither, in or at what place, relat. to τῇ, Il., Soph.
of Manner, as, ᾗ καὶ Λοξίας ἐφήμισεν Aesch., Thuc., etc.
wherefore, Lat. quare, Thuc.
in so far as, Lat. qua, quatenus, Xen.
joined with a Sup., ᾗ ἐδύνατο τάχιστα as quick as he was able, Xen.; ᾗ ῥᾷστά τε καὶ ἥδιστα Xen.

div1.head: ἦ
div1.sense: with two chief senses, Confirmative and Interrogative:

TO CONFIRM an assertion, in truth, truly, verily, of a surety, Hom., etc.; often strengthd. by other Particles, as ἦ ἄρα, ἦ δή, ἦ δή που, ἦ μάλα, etc.;—and to express doubt, ἦ που;—ἦ μήν, Ionic and Epic ἦ μέν, ἦ μάν, used in protestations and oaths, σὺ μοι ὄμοσσον, ἦ μέν μοι ἀρήξειν Hom., etc.
in INTERROG. sentences, Lat. num? pray? or can it be?— also ἦ οὐκ . . ; Lat. nonne? Particles are often added to this ἦ, ἦ ῥα, ἦ ἄρα δή, etc.

div1.head: ἠπεδανός
div1.sense: weakly, infirm, halting, Hom.
c. gen. void of a thing, Anth.

div1.head: ἠπειρογενής
div1.sense: born or living in the mainland, Aesch.

div1.head: ἤπειρόνδε
div1.sense: to the mainland, Od.

div1.head: ἤπειρος
div1.sense: terra-firma, the land, as opp. to the sea, Hom., Hes., etc.; κατʼ ἤπειρον by land, Hdt.; μήτʼ ἐν θαλάττῃ μήτʼ ἐν ἠπείρῳ Ar.:— hence in Od., even an island is called ἤπειρος.
the mainland of Western Greece, opp. to the neighbouring islands (afterwards called Ἤπειρος as n. pr.), Od.:—then, generally, the mainland, Hdt., Attic
later, a continent: Asia was esp. called the Continent, Hdt., etc.; also Europe, Aesch.; whence Soph. speaks of δισσαὶ ἤπειροι, i. e. Europe and Asia.

div1.head: ἠπειρόω
div1.sense: to make into mainland, Anth.:—Pass. to become so, Thuc.

div1.head: ἠπειρώτης
div1.sense: of the mainland, living there, opp. to νησιώτης, Hdt.: αἱ ἠπειρώτιδες πόλιες, opp. to those in islands, Hdt., etc.; ἠπ. ξυμμαχία alliance with a military power, opp. to ναυτική, Thuc.
of or on the mainland of Asia, Asiatic, Eur.
an Epirote, Luc.

div1.head: ἠπειρωτικός
div1.sense: continental, Xen.
of Epirus, Thuc.

div1.head: ἠπεροπεύς
div1.sense: a cheat, deceiver, cozener, Od., Anth.

div1.head: ἠπεροπεύω
div1.sense: to cheat, cajole, deceive, cozen, Hom.

div1.head: ᾗπερ
div1.sense: in the same way as, v. ὅσπερ.

div1.head: ἤπερ
div1.sense: than at all, than even, Hom.

div1.head: ἠπάομαι
div1.sense: to mend, repair, Ar.

div1.head: ἠπητής
div1.sense: a mender, cobbler, Batr., Xen.

div1.head: ἠπιαλέω
div1.sense: to have a fever or ague, Ar.

div1.head: ἠπίαλος
div1.sense: a fever with shivering, ague, Ar.
= ἐφιάλτης, night-mare, Ar.

div1.head: ἠπιοδίνητος
div1.sense: softly-rolling, Anth.

div1.head: ἠπιόδωρος
div1.sense: soothing by gifts, bountiful, Il.

div1.head: ἠπιόθυμος
div1.sense: gentle of mood, Anth.

div1.head: ἤπιος
div1.sense: of persons, gentle, mild, kind, πατὴρ δʼ ὣς ἤπιος ἦεν Hom.:—c. dat. pers., Hom., Trag.
of sentiments, ἤπια εἰδέναι to have kindly feelings, Hom.; πρὸς τὸ ἠπιώτερον καταστῆσαί τινα to bring him to a milder mood, Thuc.
act. soothing, assuaging, of medicines, Il., etc.
ἤπιον ἦμαρ, c. inf., a day favourable for beginning a thing, Hes.
adv. ἠπίως, Hdt., Soph.

div1.head: ἠπιόχειρ
div1.sense: with soothing hand, Anth.

div1.head: ἤπου
div1.sense: ἤ, που, = ἤ, modified by που, or perhaps, as perhaps, Hom.

div1.head: ἦπου
div1.sense: or ἦ, που, I suppose, I ween, Il., Soph., etc.: after a negat., much less, Thuc.
to ask a question, is it possible that . . ? can it be that . . ? Od., Aesch.

div1.head: ἠπύτα
div1.sense: calling, crying, ἠπύτα κῆρυξ the loud-voiced herald, Il.

div1.head: ἠπύω
div1.sense: to call to, call on, call, Od., Aesch., etc.:—c. dupl. acc., τί με τόδε χρέος ἀπύεις; why callest thou on me for this? Eur.
absol. to call out, shout, Od.; of the wind, to roar, Il.; of the lyre, to sound, Od.
to utter, speak, πατρὸς ὄνομʼ ἀπύεις Aesch.; τί ποτʼ ἀπύσω; Eur.

div1.head: Ἡραῖος
div1.sense: of Hera: Ἡραῖον (sc. ἱερόν) , the temple of Hera, Heraeum, Hdt.

div1.head: Ἡρακλέης
div1.sense: Heracles, Lat. Hercules, son of Zeus and Alcmena, the most famous of the Greek heroes, Hom., etc. (The name signifies Heraʼs glory, Ἥρας κλέος, from the power she obtained over him at birth.)

div1.head: Ἡρακλεῖδαι
div1.sense: the Heraclidae or descendants of Hercules, Hdt.

div1.head: Ἡράκλειος
div1.sense: of Hercules, Lat. Herculeus, βίη Ἡρακληείη, i. e. Hercules himself, Hom.:— Ἡρ. στῆλαι the opposite headlands of Gibraltar and Apesʼ Hill near Tangier, Hdt.
as Subst., Ἡράκλειον, Ionic -ήιον (sc. ἱερόν) , the temple of Hercules, Heracleum, Hdt., etc.
Ἡράκλεια (sc. ἱερά) , τά, his festival, Ar.

div1.head: Ἡρακλείτειος
div1.sense: of Heraclitus, Plat.

div1.head: Ἥρα
div1.sense: Hera, the Lat. Juno, queen of the gods, daughter of Kronos and Rhea, sister and wife of Zeus, Hom., etc.; νὴ τὴν Ἥραν, an oath of Athen. women, Xen.

div1.head: ἦρα
div1.sense: acceptable gifts, kindnesses, ἦρα φέρειν Hom.
= χάριν, c. gen., on account of, Anth.

div1.head: ἠρεμαῖος
div1.sense: still, quiet, gentle, Plat.:—irreg. comp. ἠρεμέστερος, Xen. adv. -αίως, ἠρέμα, Xen.; comp. -εστέρως Xen.

div1.head: ἠρέμα
div1.sense: stilly, quietly, gently, softly, Ar., Plat.
a little, slightly, Plat.
slowly, opp. to τάχιστα, Plat.

div1.head: ἠρεμέω
div1.sense: to keep quiet, be at rest, Xen., Plat.

div1.head: ἠρέμησις
div1.sense: quietude, Arist.

div1.head: ἠρεμία
div1.sense: rest, quietude, ἐπὶ ἠρεμίας ὑμῶν leaving you at rest, Dem.

div1.head: ἠρεμίζω
div1.sense: to make still or quiet, Xen.
intr. = ἠρεμέω, Xen.

div1.head: ἠριγένεια
div1.sense: early-born, child of morn, epith. of Ἠώς, Hom.; also absol., = Ἠώς, Morn, Od.; ἠριγενείας at morn, Theocr.

div1.head: Ἠριδανός
div1.sense: Eridanus, a river famous in legends, Hes., Hdt.: later authors mostly took it for the Po, as Eur.; others for the Rhone or Rhine, as perh. in Hdt.

div1.head: ἠρινός
div1.sense: of or in spring, Solon., Eur.: —neut. pl. as adv., in spring, Ar.

div1.head: ἠρίον
div1.sense: a mound, barrow, tomb, Il., Theocr.

div1.head: ἦρι
div1.sense: early, Hom.; ἦρι μάλʼ, μάλʼ ἦρι Hom.

div1.head: ἠριπόλη
div1.sense: early-walking: as Subst. the morn, Anth.

div1.head: ἡρωικός
div1.sense: of or for a hero, heroic, Plat., etc.
metrically, ἡρ. στίχος the heroic verse, the hexameter, Plat.

div1.head: ἡρωίνη
div1.sense: a heroine, Theocr.; contr. ἡρῴνη, Ar.

div1.head: ἡρωίς
div1.sense: = ἡρωίνη, Pind.
as fem. of ἡρωϊκός, Anth.

div1.head: ἡρῷον
div1.sense: the temple or chapel of a hero, Hdt., etc.; θἠρῷον, i. e. τὸ ἡρῷον, Ar.
(sub. μέτρον) , an hexameter, Plut.

div1.head: ἡρῷος
div1.sense: ὁ ἡρ. sc. ῥυθμός the heroic measure, hexameter, Plat., etc.; ποὺς ἡρ. the dactyl, Anth.

div1.head: ἥρως
div1.sense: a hero, in Hom. used of the Greeks before Troy, then of warriors generally; and then of all free men of the heroic age, as the minstrel Demodocus, the herald Mulius, even the unwarlike Phaeacians.
in Hes. the blessed heroes are the fourth age of men, who fell before Thebes and Troy, and then passed to the Islands of the Blest.

heroes, as objects of worship, demigods or men born from a god and a mortal, as Hercules, Aeneas, Memnon, Hdt., Pind.; then of such as had done great services to mankind, as Daedalus, Triptolemus, Theseus, Anth.
later, the heroes are inferior local deities, patrons of tribes, cities, guilds, founders of cities, etc.; as at Athens, the ἥρωες ἐπώνυμοι were the heroes after whom the φυλαί were named, Hdt.

div1.head: ἡσσάομαι
div1.etym: Note that middle forms such as ἡττήσομαι can have passive sense.
div1.sense: Pass. to be less than another, inferior to him, c. gen. pers., Eur., Xen., etc.; c. gen. rei, ἡ. ῥήματος to yield to the power of a word, Thuc.; ὃ ἡττῶιτο wherein he had proved inferior, Xen.
as a real Pass. to be defeated, discomfited, worsted, beaten, ὑπό τινος Hdt., Attic; also c. gen. pers., Eur., etc.;— ἡσσᾶσθαι μάχηι or μάχην Hdt., Dem.
to give way, yield, to be a slave to passion and the like, c. gen., ἡσσημένος ἔρωτος Eur.; τῶν ἡδονῶν Xen.:—also c. dat. to be overcome by, ἡδονῆι ἡσσώμενοι Thuc.

div1.head: ἧσσα
div1.sense: a defeat, discomfiture, opp. to νίκη, Thuc., etc.:—c. gen. rei, a giving way to a thing, ἡδονῶν, ἐπιθυμιῶν Plat.

div1.head: ἡσσητέος
div1.sense: one must be beaten, γυναικός by a woman, Soph.

div1.head: ἥσσων
div1.etym: formed from ἦκα, softly, so that the orig. form was ἡκίων, with Sup. ἥκιστος) :
div1.sense: c. gen. pers. less, weaker, less brave, Hom., etc.; c. inf., ἕσσων θεῖν not so good at running, Hdt.; οὐδενὸς ἥσσων γνῶναι "second to none" in judging, Thuc.

absol. of the weaker party, ἥσσους γενέσθαι to have the worst of it, Thuc.; τὰ τῶν ἡττόνων the fortunes of the vanquished, Xen.; of things, τὸν ἥττω λόγον κρείττω ποιεῖν "to make the worse appear the better reason, " Plat.
c. gen. rei, yielding to a thing, a slave to, ἔρωτος Soph.; κέρδους Ar., etc.: —generally, yielding to, unable to resist, τοῦ πεπρωμένου Eur.
neut. ἧσσον, Attic ἧττον, as adv., less, Od., Thuc., etc.:—with a negat., οὐχ ἧσσον, οὐδʼ ἧσσον not the less, just as much, Aesch., etc.

div1.head: ἡσυχάζω
div1.sense: to be still, keep quiet, be at rest, Aesch.; ἡ ἀπορία τοῦ μὴ ἡσυχάζειν the difficulty of finding rest, Thuc.:—often in part., ἡσυχάζων προσμένω Soph.; ἡσυχάσασα by resting from war, Thuc.; τὸ ἡσυχάζον τῆς νυκτός the dead of night, Thuc.
Causal in aor1, to make still, lay to rest, Plat.

div1.head: ἥσυχα
div1.etym: neut. pl. of ἥσυχος, as adv.

div1.head: ἡσυχῆ
div1.sense: stilly, quietly, softly, gently, Pind.; ἔχʼ ἡσυχῆ keep quiet, Plat.; ἡσ. γελάσαι Plat.

div1.head: ἡσυχία
div1.sense: stillness, rest, quiet, Od., Hdt., Attic:—c. gen. rest from a thing, Hdt., Plat.

with Preps., διʼ ἡσυχίης εἶναι to keep quiet, Hdt.:— ἐν ἡσ. ἔχειν τι to keep it quiet, not speak of it, Hdt.:— ἐφʼ ἡσυχίας Ar.:— κατʼ ἡσυχίην πολλήν quite at oneʼs ease, Hdt.; καθʼ ἡσυχίαν at leisure, Thuc.:— μεθʼ ἡσυχίας quietly, Eur.
with Verbs, ἡσυχίαν ἄγειν to keep quiet, be at rest, keep silent, Hdt., Attic:—so ἡσυχίαν ἔχειν Hdt., Attic
solitude, a sequestered place, Hhymn., Xen.

div1.head: ἡσύχιος
div1.sense: still, quiet, at rest, at ease, Il.; also in Prose, τρόπου ἡσυχίου of a quiet disposition, Hdt.; τὸ ἡσύχιον τῆς εἰρήνης Thuc. adv. -ίως, Hhymn.

div1.head: ἥσυχος
div1.sense: still, quiet, at rest, at ease, at leisure, Hes., Hdt., Attic; ἡσύχῳ βάσει φρενῶν, i. e. in thought, Aesch.; ἐν ἡσύχῳ quietly, Soph.

quiet, gentle, of character, Aesch., Eur., etc.; τοὺς ἀφʼ ἡσύχου ποδός those of quiet life, Eur.; ὀργῇ ὑπόθες ἥσυχον πόδα, i. e. moderate thy anger, Eur.; τὸ ξύνηθες ἥσυχον their accustomed quietness, Thuc.
the common Attic comp. and Sup. were ἡσυχαίτερος, -αίτατος, but the regular form -ώτερος is also found.
adv. -χως, Eur., etc.: gently, cautiously, Eur.:—Sup. ἡσυχαίτατα Plat.—The neut. ἥσυχον, Doric ἅσυχον, is also used as adv., Theocr.; and pl. ἅσυχα, Theocr.

div1.head: ἦτα
div1.sense: Η, η, ἦτα, τό, indecl., seventh letter of the Gr. alphabet; as numeral η ὀκτώ and ὄγδοος, but η 8000. The uncial form of Eta ( *h) was a double ε and prob. it was pronounced as a long ε, cf. δῆλος (from δέελος). The old Alphabet had only one sign ( Ε) for the ε sound, till the long vowels η and ω were introduced from the Samian Alphabet in the archonship of Euclides, B. C. 403. The sign H, before it was taken to represent the double ε, was used for the spiritus asper, as ΗΟΣ for ὅς, (which remains in the Latin H). When H was taken to represent long e, it was at the same time cut in two, so that †i† represented the spir.asper, †o† the spir. lenis; whence came the present signs for the breathings. As to dialectic changes,
the vowel η was much used by the Ionic, being in Aeolic and Doric replaced by ᾱ, as also in Attic, but mostly after ρ or a vowel, πρήσσω θώρηξ ἰητρός, Attic πράσσω θώραξ ἰατρός.
in Attic, ει and ηι were not seldom changed into ῃ, as κλεῖθρα κλῇθρα, Νηρηίδες Νηρῇδες.
Doric and Aeolic for ει, as τῆνος, κῆνος for κεῖνος.

div1.head: ἤτε
div1.sense: ἤ τε, or also, Il.

div1.head: ἦτε
div1.sense: surely, doubtless, Hom.

div1.head: ἤτοι
div1.sense: = ἦ τοι, now surely, truly, verily, Il.; after ἀλλʼ εἰ . . , nevertheless, Il.
= ἤτοι, either in truth, followed by ἤ, or, Hdt., etc.

div1.head: ἦτορ
div1.etym: in Hom. always in nom. or acc.
div1.sense: the heart as a part of the body, Il.:—then, as the seat of life, life, ἦτορ ὀλέσσαι Il.:—as the seat of feeling, the heart, Il., etc.

div1.head: ἤτριον
div1.sense: the warp in a web of cloth, Plat., Theocr.:—in pl. a thin, fine cloth, such that one could see between the threads, Eur.; ἤτρια βύβλων leaves made of strips of papyrus, Anth.

div1.head: ἦτρον
div1.sense: the part below the navel, the abdomen, Plat., Xen., etc.

div1.head: ἠΰτε
div1.sense: as, like as, Il., etc.; often in Hom. in similes for ὡς ὅτε.
in Il. 4. 277 after a comp., μελάντερον ἠύτε πίσσα very black, like as pitch, or = ἤ, blacker than pitch.

div1.head: ἠύχορος
div1.sense: with fair dances, Anth.

div1.head: Ἡφαίστειος
div1.sense: of Hephaestus: Ἡφαιστεῖον or Ἡφαίστειον (sc. ἱερόν) , temple of Hephaestus, Hdt., Dem., etc.:— Ἡφαίστεια (sc. ἱερά) , τά, his festival, the Lat. Vulcanalia, Xen.

div1.head: Ἡφαιστόπονος
div1.sense: wrought by Hephaestus, Eur.

div1.head: Ἥφαιστος
div1.sense: Hephaestus, Lat. Vulcanus, sonof Zeus and Hera, lame from birth, master of metal working, Hom., etc.
meton. for πῦρ, fire, Il., Soph.
div1.etym: Perh. from ἅπτω, to kindle fire.

div1.head: Ἡφαιστότευκτος
div1.sense: wrought by Hephaestus, Soph.

div1.head: ἠχεῖον
div1.sense: a kind of kettle-drum or gong, Plut.

div1.head: ἠχέτης
div1.sense: clear-sounding, musical, Aesch., Eur.:—of the grasshopper, chirping, Hes., Anth.; and ἀχέτας, ου, alone, the chirper, the grasshopper, Ar.

div1.head: ἠχέω
div1.sense: intr. to sound, ring, peal, Hes.; often of metal, ἤχεσκε (Ionic imperf.) Hdt.; τὰ χαλκεῖα πληγέντα μακρὸν ἠχεῖ Plat.; of the grasshopper, to chirp, Theocr.
c. acc. cogn., ἀχεῖν ὕμνον to let it sound, Aesch.; κωκυτόν Soph.; χαλκίον ἄχει sound the cymbal, Theocr.:—Pass., ἠχεῖται κτύπος a sound is made, Soph.

div1.head: ἠχήεις
div1.sense: sounding, ringing, roaring, Hom.

div1.head: ἤχημα
div1.sense: a sound, sounding, Eur.

div1.head: ἠχή
div1.sense: a sound or noise of any sort, Hom., Attic; of the confused noise of a crowd, the roar of the sea, the groaning of trees in a wind, Il., etc.:—in Trag., like ἰαχή, a cry of sorrow, wail; but, σάλπιγγος ἠχή Eur.:—rarely of articulate sounds, Eur.

div1.head: ἧχι
div1.sense: where, Hom.

div1.head: ἦχος
div1.etym: later form of ἠχή, Theocr., Mosch.

div1.head: ἠχώ
div1.sense: a sound, but properly of a returned sound, echo, Hhymn., Hes., etc.
generally, a ringing sound, Soph., Trag.; τὴν Βοιωτίην κατεῖχε ἠχὼ ὡς . . Boeotia rang with the news that . . , Hdt.

div1.head: ἠῶθεν
div1.sense: from morn, i. e. at dawn, at break of day, Hom., etc.; this morning, Od.

div1.head: ἠῷος
div1.sense: at morn, at break of day, Hhymn., Hes.
from the east, eastern, Hdt.

div1.head: ἠώς
div1.etym: Aeolic ἄυως, i. e. ἄϝως, not αὔως
div1.sense: the morning red, daybreak, dawn, Hom., Hdt., etc.:— morning as a time of day, opp. to μέσον ἦμαρ and δείλη, Il.; gen. ἠοῦς at morn, early, Il.; ἠῶ the morning long, Od.:— ἐξ ἠοῦς μέχρι δείλης ὀψίης Hdt.:— ἅμα ἠοῖ at daybreak, Hdt.; ἅμʼ ἕῳ or ἅμα τῇ ἕῳ Thuc.; Epic ἠῶθι πρό Hom.; ἐς ἀῶ to-morrow, Theocr.
since the Greeks counted their days by mornings, ἠώς often denoted a day, Hom.
the East, Hom.; ἀπὸ ἠοῦς πρὸς ἑσπέρην Hdt., etc.
as prop. n. Ἠώς, Aurora, the goddess of morn, who rises out of her ocean-bed, Il., Eur.
